course.subject: COMP
course.name: Introduction to Blockchain, Cryptocurrencies and Smart Contracts
course.description: This course provides a holistic introduction to the world of Blockchain Protocols and Smart Contracts. You will learn how cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin and Ethereum work, why they are secure, and how you can use them to develop smart contracts. You will also learn to detect and avoid common security vulnerabilities in smart contracts. This is a very hands-on course with lots of extra-credit homeworks and mini-projects and no final exam. The course covers the following topics: basics of cryptography, the double-spending problem in decentralized currencies, Proof-of-work and its alternatives, programmable blockchains and smart contracts, auctions and escrows, common smart contract vulnerabilities, and tools for verifying the correctness of a smart contract.
course.prerequisites: COMP 2012 AND (COMP 2711 OR COMP 2711H OR MATH 2343)

reviews.comment_workload:
Ustspace has a weird definition on workload. A is very light, B is light, C is average.

Reasonable workload. Since there is no midterm or final, the assignments and the project are relatively more challenging. The marking is forgiving such that you can resubmit once for each assignment (not project) after receiving feedback. Students are required to finish the project on their own without any discussion with peers. That's why it requires weeks to complete the project.

As announced by the professor, a few students had been caught plagiarism in the assignments. This fact is a huge deterrent to cheating in this course.

reviews.author: McBoy
reviews.title: Great course, amazing lecturer
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:
- Hash Functions and Public key cryptography
- Double spending problem
- Bitcoin and proof of work
- Proof of stake and other alternatives to proof of work
- programmable blockchains
- introduction to Ethereum
- implementing smart contracts in solidity
- commitment schemes
- auctions and escrows
- reentrancy and out-of-gas vulnerabilities
- incentivization bugs
- verifying the correctness of smart contracts


This course is about:
- Decentralization and its benefits
- Privacy-preserving technologies
- Understanding the big ideas in Bitcoin and Ethereum
- smart contract programming in Solidity
- Vulnerabilities in Smart Contracts
- Security Analysis
reviews.comment_teaching:
One of the best lecturers in the CSE department for sure. Answers your questions by email quickly, gives great feedback, and has very fluent English.

Homework questions (especially bonus questions) may not be topics taught in the class, but of course, we are CS students, and this is a 4000-level course. We should at least be proficient at googling and not rely on the lecturer spoon-feeding us all the answers for the homework, especially as there are no exams in this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Doing all the required assignments and the final project perfectly will give you 100 points. However, there are also bonus points (up to 25). I received over 100 points, but the official grades are not out yet. There are rumors that the grading scheme will be changed by the CSE department, but we will have to wait and see.

If we use the original grading scheme as agreed at the beginning of the semester, it is a very good grading course.

UPDATE:
How the f*** is 114 A-???????? I did not do the bonus points knowing for sure I will get over 100 points. Now I get A- WOW.

UPDATE 2:
They finally changed my grade to A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
No exams, 7 assignments (coding + report), and 1 project. There are a lot of bonus points in the homework and in the final project. If you don't do the bonus, the workload is quite low. The bonus questions usually are trickier and may not be taught in the class.

The workload is for sure way lower than Prof Golin's COMP3711 or COMP3711H class, even including the bonus questions if you know how to research and use google. Keep in mind that there are no exams in this course, so the number of assignments is completely justified.

reviews.author: V8_BITURBO
reviews.comment_content:
1.Hash Functions and Public-key Cryptography
2.The Double-spending Problem
3.Bitcoin and Proof-of-Work (PoW)
4.Proof-of-stake and other alternatives to PoW
5.Programmable Blockchains
6.Introduction to Ethereum and Solidity
7.Implementing Smart Contracts
8.Commitment Schemes
9.Auctions and Escrows
10.Re-entrancy and Out-of-gas Vulnerabilities
11.Incentivization Bugs
12.Verifying Correctness of Smart Contracts

The first half of the course mainly focus on theories of blockchain, like cryptography schemes, hash functions and the basic working principles of blockchain.
The second half is to teach you to code your smart contract with solidity. This language is very similar to  C++. Writing codes is the easiest part even if you get a B- in COMP2011, understanding the cybersecurity concepts would be much more important.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof.'s English was very fluent and had almost no accent. He did not use any textbooks or materials, but directly wrote  the corresponding content while lecturing. There was no difference between the lecture session and the lab session. Both of them are simply lectures. The concepts were explained in detail, but they were not enough for completing the assignments.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is the most wonderful and dramatic part of this course. It is a This is an EVEN MORE OUTRAGEOUS AND EXAGGERATED DISASTER then COMP3021!!!

There is no midterm and final exam. Instead, there are 7 assignments and 1 final project. Each assignment carries 10% of your total grade and the final project worths 30%. For each of the assignment, every student got a chance of resubmit if they did not obtain full mark. Apart from this, you can obtain a 15% bonus for assignments and 10% for the final project.

It is hard to tell the actual mean scores for the assignment part as everyone could resubmit. But obviously, it would be very close to 100%. The mean score for the final project is 27.9/30.

My scores:
Assignments 70/70 + 4 bonus.
Final Project 25/30 + 5 bonus.
Overall: 100/100

I thought I would definitely get a A+ for this course. But guess what, the department changed the grading scheme at the final moment. The full mark for this course is updated into 125, and grades will be distributed by a standard way of "拉curve". So my marks become 104/125.

This is much more ironic than the situation in COMP3021. I don't know why there's no one even discuss about it, as there are 125 students in this coures, even more than COMP3021.
reviews.comment_workload: As I mentioned in the teaching part, the content taught during the lectures are not enough for you to complete the assignments, especially for the first 3 of them. You have to do a lot of research on yourself to discover the answers, from the Internet forums, the bitcoin white book and even some research papers. If you aim full marks on the assignments, then the workload for each of them will be as much as an COMP3711 assignment.
